post.body: At least for the past few months, everywhere I go on ruqqus people seem to have a huge fetish for men being "men" and dominating their women. I don't really care but it seems to prevail almost universally on ruqqus for some reason, in a manner similar to how almost everyone on deviantart and twitter is a furry. It can become annoying when it begins to invade serious discussion though. For instance I just saw a post complaining that female soldiers exist. People often even express disappointment that girls sports are a thing. And any time someone suggests that women beat men in anything, the bandwagon attacks it and insists otherwise with zero evidence but their kink. It seems like ruqqus is obsessed with the female being weak and dominated by the male, to the point where they think the whole world should be set up and legislated to reflect their fetish. This isn't abnormal (though to the degree of wanting to impose it on everyone is) but I wonder why it's so prevalent here? There are obvious reasons why art sites tend to attract furries and weebs, but I'm confused about how discussion forums attract "alpha males" so much.

body:
Hate to burst your pride bubble but pretty much anything that isn't physio-spatial women have so much more potential. It's all down to how brains are configured and what tasks people are meant for. Biologically, males serve primarily 2 functions: sperm donor and provide/protect. It's a nasty role and not very fun but someone has to do it. Males lose their childhood "sponge" learning and enormous creativity over time in exchange for physio-spatial skills, while girls develop them further. You may wonder why one sex is more well rounded and the other overspecializes so much in just this one area, but in ancient times physical strength was a BIG deal. But it is a fact that male brains are designed to be good at perceiving pain, becoming angry and demanding justice, and noticing moving objects, and female brains are designed to be good at logic, creativity, and nurturing, and considering the historical roles of each, this setup makes perfect sense, fair or not.

There is a common misconception that males are more variable and excel both at being god awful at something or insanely good, while women are more centered around the average. Males being more variable is true, however technically female abilities average far higher than male ones, as shown by brain scans. The reason they often don't achieve as much is that men are more competitive and more likely to try and turn a hobby into a career or financial success, whereas women tend to do things more just for fun in private. The other reason is that, also due to primal instincts, society coddles girls and is too harsh on boys. Boys, even from a young age, must NEVER cry, NEVER fail, NEVER make mistakes, etc. while girls are allowed to basically have temper tantrums over the smallest things and be comparatively lazy (as they are not required to provide for themselves like men). What this results in is that boys are constantly worrying about doing their job well enough, while girls concern themselves with gossip and makeup which of course is going to make them stupid; the fact that they maintain average intelligence doing this is amazing. However, the ones that have enough interest to push themselves even a little bit are fucking savants; the highest IQ on record is in fact a woman's. This reflects my personal experience pretty well also, if you ask for 10 geniuses, you'll get 9 men but one girl who is more brilliant than half of them combined. Female is definitely the superior sex when it comes to natural talent, you'll see a man talented in one or two things every once in a while but the *majority* of girls have a ton of talents, some seem to be talented at every single thing there is; whether they tend use them or waste them is another story.

post.body: At least for the past few months, everywhere I go on ruqqus people seem to have a huge fetish for men being "men" and dominating their women. I don't really care but it seems to prevail almost universally on ruqqus for some reason, in a manner similar to how almost everyone on deviantart and twitter is a furry. It can become annoying when it begins to invade serious discussion though. For instance I just saw a post complaining that female soldiers exist. People often even express disappointment that girls sports are a thing. And any time someone suggests that women beat men in anything, the bandwagon attacks it and insists otherwise with zero evidence but their kink. It seems like ruqqus is obsessed with the female being weak and dominated by the male, to the point where they think the whole world should be set up and legislated to reflect their fetish. This isn't abnormal (though to the degree of wanting to impose it on everyone is) but I wonder why it's so prevalent here? There are obvious reasons why art sites tend to attract furries and weebs, but I'm confused about how discussion forums attract "alpha males" so much.

I don't see this as any kind of fetish. It's simply because conservatives tend to think (more compared to progressives and other groups) that men outperform women in physical strength, that they put on a better show in most sports, that women are worth protecting instead of sending them to the battle etc. Now because conservatives have been largely driven out of places like reddit or twitter you'll find their opinions prevail in whatever place where they find refuge. Ruqqus in this case. Without social media censorship these opinions would be mixed together with other opinions across various platforms.

It's like asking why Twitter user base is so obsessed with mental illnesses and being furries. After people with other views were kicked out they are all that is left.

body: We can be pretty certain that 7 of Paul's letters are authentic, albeit with later additions but those are usually easy to detect. But more importantly, we have 4 gospels which are self-evidently the truth. And they agree with each other enough that two of them even incorporated parts of the earlier ones into their own text. Paul also agrees with what is taught in the gospels, even though he wrote his epistles before any gospel had yet been written. All of these, both Pauline letters and gospels, we have in the original languages (Greek), except for Matthew which was originally composed in Hebrew (and we do actually have a complete hebrew copy of matthew, albeit corrupted, which shows signs of having been an original 1st century composition and not a translation from the greek. It is preserved by jewish rabbi Shem Tov in his 14th century work *The Touchstone*).

One of my many repeated problems in my attempts to embrace Christianity is that I can't get that into a belief system where so much hinges on how someone interprets someone's translation of what someone said 2000 years ago, but ALSO I'm supposed to have faith that there's a plan and this all somehow works out.

Whatever I believe has to be based first and foremost on what I can see in front of me in the world as it exists today because I can't take for granted any of what I'm told about the past, lies get exponentially easier for the powerful as you go further back in history.

Even if I could will myself to believe in Jesus' message, I can't make myself believe in some guy's interpretation of some guy's translation of some guy's argument based on some guy's misreading of a letter by a guy who followed jesus except the letter may have been forged.

post.body:
The pastoral epistles, known to most as 1 & 2 Timothy and Titus, were not written by Paul but forged in his name by the church fathers who sought to combat an early heretic named Marcion. Marcion insisted on a literal interpretation of the old testament and believed that the creator and old testament god was an evil tyrant and lesser god opposed to the father of Christ. He and his followers were vegans, did not procreate, and had all kinds of ridiculous rules (ironic given their gripe about the old testament). Marcion also said Paul was the only apostle.

Unfortunately the church became reactionary and instead of being honest wrote these epistles for Paul to disprove Marcion. The entirety of the pastorals reads like a summary of Marcionism:

* False teachers are forbidding eating certain foods and marriage (Marcionite veganism and anti-procreation) (1 Timothy 4:3) "[false teachers] forbidding to marry, to abstain from foods which God created for use with thankfulness by the faithful and knowing of the truth"

* Seeking marriage is commanded and procreation and Roman family structure is the most central part of life, and church officials must both be husbands and have well-liked children (1 Timothy 3:4-5, Titus 1:5-6). In fact, bearing children is even set as a requirement for salvation (1 Timothy 2:15) "But [women] will be saved by the bearing of children...".

* Women must be silent and submissive housewives and mothers (lots of women were high up in Marcion's assembly) (1 Timothy 2:11-2:14, 1 Timothy 5:14 and several other passages)

* The law is portrayed in a very positive light and good works are essential (Marcion did not think highly of the OT law)

* Uses the "shipwreck" analogy (and Marcion was a ship trader) (1 Timothy 1:19).

* Complains about jewish myths constantly (Strange as it sounds, Marcion was called a Judaizer by the church fathers for his interpretation of the OT).

* The pastorals seem to teach the idea that Jesus was merely a man mediating for the OT God (to contrast with Marcion's belief that the OT God was separate from Christ's) (1 Timothy 2:5) "For there is one God, and one mediator of God and men, the MAN Anointed Jesus"

We know that Marcion was in error about a great many things. However it seems that the early church was more concerned with defeating their enemies than being honest. Instead, they wrote the pastoral epistles in the name of Marcion's favorite apostle, which simply proclaim everything the opposite of Marcion. This reactionary nature does not accurately represent Paul, so any attempt to claim it was one of his students writing for him does not stand. While Paul clearly disagreed with Marcion in many ways, in any case where Paul *does* agree with Marcion the pastorals disagree with him in order to disagree with Marcion:

* Real Paul never frowned upon marriage as did Marcion, but commended the unmarried as having done better, opposite of the pastoral theology (1 Corinthians 7)

* Real Paul believed the OT law to be a stumbling block which leads to sin. It was fulfilled and freedom in Christ is emphasized (Romans 7).

* Real Paul was not hesitant to hold women high regard or employ them in high positions (Romans 16)

* Real Paul concerned himself not with the things of this world, but the next, assuring that this one is only a vapor in time and does not matter. "Paul" of the pastorals however was primarily concerned with conforming to Greco-Roman social norms, marriage & procreation, organized church structure, and the affairs of this life. Some of it appears to be developing Catholicism.

I would not advise putting much trust in the pastoral epistles. They were not from a faithful follower but some reactionary church father. They teach several other problematic commands, such as abandoning widows (1 Timothy 5) and possibly even condoning slavery (1 Timothy 6:1-2, but the language is unclear). "Peter's" epistles and Jude and James (which teaches a works salvation btw) are probably counterfeits as well. Ephesians, Colossians, 2 Thessalonians, and most of the non-Pauline epistles all have a good chance of not being authentic, and possibly even Revelation. Of course we could also just follow Jesus instead of men and this wouldn't be much of a problem in the first place.

body: Yep, that was pretty much my last point. I do however think that Paul's authentic letters are valuable as they give good insight to the very early Christian world from before the gospels were even written, so he counts as an early witness like the authors of the gospels, albeit in a different form. The Pauline epistles can also be useful for detecting later edits to the text of the gospels. And Paul is also a trustworthy man of high understanding when read correctly, and while not our teacher is well worth listening to.

  • Women must be silent and submissive housewives and mothers (lots of women were high up in Marcion's assembly) (1 Timothy 2:11-2:14, 1 Timothy 5:14 and several other passages)

  • The law is portrayed in a very positive light and good works are essential (Marcion did not think highly of the OT law)

  • Uses the "shipwreck" analogy (and Marcion was a ship trader) (1 Timothy 1:19).

  • Complains about jewish myths constantly (Strange as it sounds, Marcion was called a Judaizer by the church fathers for his interpretation of the OT).

  • The pastorals seem to teach the idea that Jesus was merely a man mediating for the OT God (to contrast with Marcion's belief that the OT God was separate from Christ's) (1 Timothy 2:5) "For there is one God, and one mediator of God and men, the MAN Anointed Jesus"

We know that Marcion was in error about a great many things. However it seems that the early church was more concerned with defeating their enemies than being honest. Instead, they wrote the pastoral epistles in the name of Marcion's favorite apostle, which simply proclaim everything the opposite of Marcion. This reactionary nature does not accurately represent Paul, so any attempt to claim it was one of his students writing for him does not stand. While Paul clearly disagreed with Marcion in many ways, in any case where Paul does agree with Marcion the pastorals disagree with him in order to disagree with Marcion:

  • Real Paul never frowned upon marriage as did Marcion, but commended the unmarried as having done better, opposite of the pastoral theology (1 Corinthians 7)

  • Real Paul believed the OT law to be a stumbling block which leads to sin. It was fulfilled and freedom in Christ is emphasized (Romans 7).

  • Real Paul was not hesitant to hold women high regard or employ them in high positions (Romans 16)

  • Real Paul concerned himself not with the things of this world, but the next, assuring that this one is only a vapor in time and does not matter. "Paul" of the pastorals however was primarily concerned with conforming to Greco-Roman social norms, marriage & procreation, organized church structure, and the affairs of this life. Some of it appears to be developing Catholicism.

I would not advise putting much trust in the pastoral epistles. They were not from a faithful follower but some reactionary church father. They teach several other problematic commands, such as abandoning widows (1 Timothy 5) and possibly even condoning slavery (1 Timothy 6:1-2, but the language is unclear). "Peter's" epistles and Jude and James (which teaches a works salvation btw) are probably counterfeits as well. Ephesians, Colossians, 2 Thessalonians, and most of the non-Pauline epistles all have a good chance of not being authentic, and possibly even Revelation. Of course we could also just follow Jesus instead of men and this wouldn't be much of a problem in the first place.
post.title: 1 & 2 Timothy and Titus, why they were forged and teach false doctrines

body: Oral tradition, the way everything was passed down in ancient times. Genesis is an interesting book, as it is not one single narrative but a collection of many different writings about pre-Mosaic times, which sometimes conflict with each other (see the two very different creation stories in Genesis 1 and Genesis 2 for example) but generally show a solid timeline. The earliest parts of it are actually corrected versions of Sumerian texts, who lived immediately after the flood and were aware of the creation and flood, and recorded it (albeit a corrupted pagan version) thousands of years earlier in the Sumerian language, which was probably Abraham's mother tongue (parts of these texts are extant today in excavated tablets). This is one step of translation and transmission from corrupted Sumerian to corrected Hebrew (maybe one or two more depending on how Noah got his information) but Enoch would've had to go through way more of them, at least 2 or 3 already if we had it in Hebrew, and we only have the Ethiopic translation which itself was not even translated from the Hebrew text, but from an earlier Greek translation of this Hebrew! It's difficult to think the book could've been copied since pre-flood times, especially given that writing seems to have been invented by the enslaved Hebrews in Egypt, but even if it had been the text in our possession is so unreliable that it's probably not even worth reading. The scribes have damaged the main biblical books enough already, imagine what 2-3 times as many centuries and 3-4 translations away from the original is like.

body:
This is a myth. Many of the founding fathers were not believers and almost none of them were the great people we portray them as today. George Washington the character who couldn't tell a lie and hated tyranny is very far removed from the real one who supported tyrannical federal government, slavery, and censorship, and slaughtered his enemies. Others wanted a new monarchy (Hamilton), and some were known crooks (and Ben Franklin probably killed the person whose body was hidden in his basement). The only thing they had in common was that they didn't like King George III. Eventually they did agree on our constitution and checks on government power but only because a few of them fought for it.

The concept of a "Christian nation" is also false. That only happened one time ever, and it was NOT the United States. It was Israel, and even then they were not a good role model.

The only thing they had in common was that they didn't like King George III. guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

That is the Shelob living down inside the cavernous tunnels of our hearts.
